semantic_title: Excludes1 Notes - Pure Exclusion Rules for Mutually Exclusive Conditions
section_path: Section I > A. Conventions > 12. Excludes Notes > a. Excludes1

content.full_text: A type 1 Excludes note is a pure excludes note. It means "NOT CODED HERE!" An Excludes1 note indicates that the code excluded should never be used at the same time as the code above the Excludes1 note. An Excludes1 is used when two conditions cannot occur together, such as a congenital form versus an acquired form of the same condition. An exception to the Excludes1 definition is the circumstance when the two conditions are unrelated to each other. If it is not clear whether the two conditions involving an Excludes1 note are related or not, query the provider. (Evidence: pg no: 10, L23-L29)
content.summary: Excludes1 notes indicate codes that should never be used together except when conditions are clearly unrelated (Evidence: pg no: 10, L23-L29)
key_concepts: Pure excludes note meaning NOT CODED HERE (Evidence: pg no: 10, L23)
Codes excluded should never be used simultaneously (Evidence: pg no: 10, L23-L24)
Exception exists for unrelated conditions (Evidence: pg no: 10, L27)
Provider query required when relationship unclear (Evidence: pg no: 10, L28)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Excludes1 codes should never be used at the same time as the code above the Excludes1 note (Evidence: pg no: 10, L23-L24)
detailed_rules.explanation: This is a pure exclusion rule that prevents coding mutually exclusive conditions together (Evidence: pg no: 10, L23-L24)
common_applications: Congenital versus acquired forms of same condition

detailed_rules.rule_text: Exception applies when two conditions are unrelated to each other (Evidence: pg no: 10, L27)
detailed_rules.explanation: When conditions involving Excludes1 note are clearly unrelated, both codes may be reported (Evidence: pg no: 10, L27-L29)
common_applications: Multiple unrelated conditions in same patient

workflow_steps: Step 1: Identify Excludes1 note under code
Step 2: Determine if conditions are related or unrelated
Step 3: If related, use only one code
Step 4: If unrelated, both codes may be used
Step 5: Query provider if relationship unclear

specific_codes.description: Other somatoform disorders with Excludes1 note for sleep related teeth grinding (Evidence: pg no: 10, L28)
specific_codes.context: Example of Excludes1 exception for unrelated conditions

breakdown.F45.8: Other somatoform disorders including psychogenic dysmenorrhea

specific_codes.description: Sleep related teeth grinding excluded from F45.8 (Evidence: pg no: 10, L28-L29)
specific_codes.context: Can be coded with F45.8 when patient has both unrelated conditions

coding_scenarios.scenario: Patient with both psychogenic dysmenorrhea and sleep-related teeth grinding
coding_scenarios.documentation_example: Patient presents with psychogenic dysmenorrhea and unrelated sleep-related teeth grinding
step_by_step: Step 1: Note F45.8 has Excludes1 for G47.63

correct_coding.rationale: Conditions are clearly unrelated despite Excludes1 note (Evidence: pg no: 10, L28-L29)

incorrect_coding.rationale: Would miss the sleep disorder which is unrelated
incorrect_coding.common_mistake: Automatically excluding all Excludes1 codes without considering relationship

breakdown.F45.8: Other somatoform disorders (Evidence: pg no: 10, L28)
breakdown.G47.63: Sleep related teeth grinding (Evidence: pg no: 10, L28)

examples.rationale: Exception applies because conditions are unrelated (Evidence: pg no: 10, L29)

warnings: Never use Excludes1 codes together unless conditions are clearly unrelated (Evidence: pg no: 10, L27)
Query provider when relationship between conditions is unclear (Evidence: pg no: 10, L28)
best_practices: Carefully evaluate relationship between conditions before applying exception (Evidence: pg no: 10, L27-L29)
Document rationale for using exception rule
common_mistakes: Automatically excluding all Excludes1 codes without considering unrelated exception
Failing to query provider when relationship is unclear
tips: Look for clear clinical separation between conditions
Consider whether conditions could logically coexist
implementation_notes: Provider documentation should support unrelated nature
clinical_context: Congenital versus acquired forms are typically mutually exclusive
Unrelated conditions may coincidentally occur in same patient
